seriesJson.title: Oral essays on education
seriesJson.description: The thoughts of distinguished Americans in a survey of American eduction.

node.title: Dr. Ernest O. Melby
node.description: Dr. Ernest O. Melby, distinguished professor of education, Michigan State University, on "A Last Look."

node.title: Dr. George S. Counts
node.description: Dr. George S. Counts, distinguished visiting professor, College of Education, Michigan State University, on "The Red Blackboard."

node.title: Arthur S. Flemming
node.description: Arthur S. Flemming, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, on "Pursuit of Excellence."

node.title: Dr. Henry Steele Commager
node.description: Dr. Henry Steele Commager, professor of history, Amherst College, on "The Public Enterprise."

node.title: Norman Cousins
node.description: Norman Cousins, editor, The Saturday Review, on "A Defense."

node.title: Charles A. Siepmann
node.description: Charles A. Siepmann on "Rivals or Allies?"

node.title: William Benton
node.description: William Benton, publisher and chairman of the Encyclopedia Britannica, on "New Challenge, New Techniques."

node.title: Dr. Margaret Mead
node.description: Dr. Margaret Mead on "Can Education Change?"

node.title: Fred Hechinger
node.description: Fred Hechinger, educational editor of the New York Times, on "A Common Understanding"

node.title: Dr. Arthur S. Adams
node.description: Dr. Arthur S. Adams, former president of the American Council on Education, on "Where Do We Stand?"

node.title: Hubert Humphrey
node.description: Senator Hubert Humphrey on "The Here and Now."

node.title: Charles A. Siepmann
node.description: Charles A. Siepmann, professor of education, New York University, on "A Focal Point of Democracy."

node.title: Dr. Margaret Mead
node.description: Dr. Margaret Mead, "Education in Our American Culture." Dr. Mead is Associate Curator of Ethnology, American Museum of Natural History.
